data.title: Around Mr. Yasunari Kawabata (1968)
data.meta_description: The day after Yasunari Kawabata won the Nobel Prize in Literature, a talk was held at Kawabata's residence in Kamakura. Yukio Mishima, who admires Kawabata, and Sei Ito, a literary critic, celebrate the first honor of the Japanese people, and this is a valuable opportunity for the three to meet and talk.
data.text:
Watched on Youtube with auto-generated subtitles that are as good as you'd expect.

The day after his Nobel Prize was announced, a very tired Yasunari Kawabata was visited by Yukio Mishima, the acclaimed novelist who would in two years attempt to a military coup to restore the emperor of Japan and, upon failure, commit seppuku, and Sei Ito, literary critic and poet, and their conversation was filmed. Other than the auspicious occasion and people, this is basically a home video. I'm sure I missed a lot of nuance from the poor subtitles, but I still found it worthwhile.

Kawabata says that his laziness is the root of his success, that he slacks off, that his creative work is very painfulâ€¦
